Abstract: More and 150 people held hostage on a hijacked Indian Airlines plane for eight days arrive safely in New Delhi from Afghanistan after India secures their freedom by agreeing to release three jailed militants; five hijackers leave plan in Kandahar, Afghanistan, where they are joined by the released militants, who include a Muslim cleric named Maulana Masood Azhar; analysts say hijacking may have long-term political consequences in region, helping to legitimize Taliban, Afghan group that helped to end crisis, and further souring relations between India and Pakistan, which Indian officials and press have portrayed as hidden hand behind the hijacking; criticism in India over government's handling of hijacking intensifies in hours after hostages' release militants; photos (M)
Snippet: More and 150 people held hostage on a hijacked Indian Airlines plane for eight days arrive safely in New Delhi from Afghanistan after India secures their freedom by agreeing to release three jailed militants; five hijackers leave plan in Kandahar,...
LeadParagraph: Haggard and exhausted, more than 150 people held hostage on a hijacked jet for eight days arrived here tonight from Afghanistan after India secured their freedom by agreeing to release three jailed militants.

Headline.Main: Hostages Land in India After Deal Is Made With Hijackers
Headline.PrintHeadline: Hostages Land in India After Deal Is Made With Hijackers
